docs.lead_paragraph: BOWING to intense pressure from neighborhood and labor groups, a real estate developer has just given up plans to include a Wal-Mart store in a mall in Queens, thereby blocking Wal-Mart's plan to open its first store in New York City. In the eyes of Wal-Mart's detractors, the Arkansas-based chain embodies the worst kind of economic exploitation: it pays its 1.2 million American workers an average of only $9.68 an hour, doesn't provide most of them with health insurance, keeps out unions, has a checkered history on labor law and turns main streets into ghost towns by sucking business away from small retailers.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Robert B Reich says today's economy offers Americans Faustian bargain: it can give consumers deals largely because it hammers workers and communities; says neighborhood and labor groups may oppose opening of Wal-Mart store, but customers are lured with its low prices; says this applies to other industries as well, as people look to Internet for lower prices on merchandise, airline tickets, etc; says there must be laws and regulations that make purchases social as well as personal choices; says law requiring higher pay and health benefits for employees may raise price of goods and services, but citizen in him thinks they are worth the price (M)
docs.snippet: Wal-Mart has not become the world's largest retailer by putting a gun to our heads and forcing us to shop there.

docs.lead_paragraph: TODD A. SMITH is one of the nation's leading medical malpractice lawyers, renowned and feared in the courtroom, having extracted a lengthy string of multimillion-dollar settlements and verdicts from doctors, hospitals and insurers over the years. Though wealthy even by the standards of his profession, Mr. Smith, 55, seems to have lost none of the intensity and passion that fuel his 12- to 14-hour workdays and make him a persuasive trial lawyer. Seated in his law firm's conference room, with an Olympian view high above Lake Michigan, Mr. Smith recited the details of his first courtroom victory in the summer of 1977, when he was a $12,000-a-year assistant public defender in the Cook County criminal courts. The defendant, he recalled, was an American Indian who was accused of armed robbery in a case that was based mainly on his race. The man was identified as the robber, for example, in a lineup that included him and a collection of off-duty, white police officers. ''It was terribly unfair,'' Mr. Smith said.
docs.abstract: Article on Bush administration's next target: medical malpractice lawyers; Bush, in January speech in Illinois, again called for strict limits on medical malpractice suits, including 'hard cap of $250,000' on what patients could recover for non-economic damages like physical and emotional pain and suffering; health care analysts, while agreeing that medical liability system is deeply flawed, also agree that solution offered by administration and Republican Congress addresses only one aspect of problem; photos; graph (L)
docs.snippet: The president's plan to cap awards would help lower costs but would do little to reduce medical errors or compensate injured patients, say health care analysts.

docs.lead_paragraph: YOUR humble servant grew up as the son of two brilliant economists. I studied economics at Columbia University under some big names in economics, including C.Lowell Harriss. When I was in law school at Yale, I took classes in finance in the graduate school of economics under geniuses like James Tobin, later a Nobel Prize winner, and Henry C. Wallich, inventor of the Fed Model for when stocks or bonds are overpriced. None of these people, however, taught me to be a great investor. I have been a stockholder of Berkshire Hathaway, Warren Buffett's company, for more than 20 years, and I have done well with the stock. But even reading Mr. Buffett's famous annual letters to stockholders did not teach me to be a great investor.

headline.main: Want to Be a Fairly Good Investor? Follow the Paw Prints

docs.abstract: Ben Stein Everybody's Business column offers tips on how to be a fairly good investor; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The basic advice for being a better investor, if followed over a long period, can be life-changing.

docs.lead_paragraph: Alarmed by soaring Medicaid costs, the nation's governors say they are enchanted with some of President Bush's proposals to restructure the program, but they adamantly oppose budget cuts sought by the White House and Republican leaders of Congress. Governors and state legislators, already cutting back Medicaid benefits and eligibility, said they needed every federal dollar they could get.

headline.main: Governors Prepare to Fight Medicaid Cuts

docs.abstract: National Governors Assn is working on bipartisan strategy to oppose Pres Bush's plan to cut $60 billion from projected federal Medicaid spending over next decade; governors of both parties want more freedom to manage and reconfigure Medicaid and welcome Bush's proposal to give states discretion to decide who gets what benefits; seek more leeway to pay for long-term care in community rather than nursing homes favored by Medicaid; oppose Bush proposal to cut payments to states for administrative costs of state Medicaid agencies; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The nation's governors say they are enchanted with some of President Bush's proposals to restructure Medicaid but they oppose cuts to federal Medicaid spending.

docs.lead_paragraph: ANDREW NORTHSHIELD, firefighter and Marine reservist, had just returned from a five-month stint in Iraq in the summer of 2003 when he got a curious call at the firehouse. The City of Rye had kept his health insurance plan up and running while he was gone, a City Hall official told him, and now the firefighter had to pony up his employee contributions for that period.

headline.main: Soldiers Wage Battle at Home Over Wages

docs.abstract: Article on clumsy and sometimes contentious readjustment taking place between employers and employees in Westchester County, NY, as military reservists and members of National Guard return from deployment in Iraq; 1994 federal law provides strong protections regarding vacation, pension and health care benefits and reclaiming jobs but provides no guidance over pay; informal survey of municipalities in Westchester County finds that most have been providing differential pay since September 11 attacks; photo (M)
docs.snippet: ANDREW NORTHSHIELD, firefighter and Marine reservist, had just returned from a five-month stint in Iraq in the summer of 2003 when he got a curious call at the firehouse.    The City of Rye had kept his health insurance plan up and running while he...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Internal Revenue Service received more than 570,000 tax returns from people who listed themselves as artists, writers and performers last year, but many of them probably did not have a clue about what they could claim as legal deductions, said Conard Fowkes, a veteran actor who helped found a free income tax assistance program, cosponsored by the I.R.S., for professional actors and stage managers in New York. ''One of the things we say, partly in jest, is that if you heard it in the dressing room, don't believe it,'' he said. Here's a short primer of reasonable tax deductions artists can trust. As the typical tax disclaimer goes: individual circumstances may vary. And be sure to save those receipts. COSTUMES: For the most part, the cost of an actor's clothing cannot be deducted as a business expense, even if it is worn solely for an audition, a rehearsal or onstage. Nor can garb purchased to wear on the red carpet at the Oscars tonight. There is one notable exception: ''If you can't sit down in it, like some clown costume or some science-fictiony thing, you can treat it as a professional expense,'' said Frederick M. Stein, a tax lawyer and analyst for RIA, the tax and accounting publishing house. HEALTH CARE: Most medical and dental expenses are not fully deductible for actors and artists. Elective procedures like breast enhancement and teeth whitening almost never are. But as one benchmark case suggests, dental work caused by an on-the-job accident can qualify. In the 1920's, Reginald Denny, an actor under contract with Universal, succeeded in getting a business expense deduction of the full $400 he paid for dental bridgework. The reason: his teeth were knocked out during the filming of a boxing movie. PROFESSIONAL TRAINING: Ordinary enthusiasts cannot deduct the cost of professional training like private voice lessons or a dance class. But for working performers, Mr. Fowkes said, those costs can qualify as educational expenses if the coaching improves a specific skill set. Hilary Swank, for example, could deduct the cost of the boxing training she received for her role in ''Million Dollar Baby'' if she paid for it out of pocket. Still, health club and gym memberships are generally not deductible. From the I.R.S. standpoint, the cost of keeping fit is considered a personal expense. WORKSPACE: A professional artist can deduct a portion of the cost of a home studio, whether rented or owned, if there is proper documentation. The sculptor, for example, who dedicates some space in his home exclusively and regularly for his work can deduct a percentage of the rent as a business expense. For the artist who owns, a share of the depreciation on the house is deductible as well as a portion of the insurance and utility costs. Depreciation on specialized business equipment, like a kiln, is also deductible. Of course, one writer went too far. In the 1990's, Pennel Phlander Irwin, an unpublished novelist, tried to claim that all his living expenses were deductible because his entire life went into his writing. As one might expect, the I.R.S shot that claim down. SUPPLIES: Professional artists are entitled to take a tax deduction for materials they use in their art. The painter can deduct the cost of his paints; the photographer, the cost of her film. The performance artist? ''If you buy chocolate sauce to smear all over yourself while doing a piece of performance art, then yeah, you can go ahead and deduct it,'' Mr. Stein said. Just be sure you can prove that it was being used for business purposes. ERIC DASH
docs.abstract: Short primer of reasonable tax deductions that artists, writers and performers can take; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A short primer of reasonable tax deductions for artists, writers and performers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Joshua Noble, a 21-year-old who loves to snowboard, jolted Wal-Mart Stores last November when he got a majority of employees here at the Wal-Mart tire-and-lube shop where he worked to sign statements saying they wanted to vote on bringing in a labor union. The unionization drive begun by Mr. Noble created a storm in this onetime ranching town at the foot of the Rockies -- even the BBC covered it -- and became a closely watched test of labor's efforts to unionize the world's largest retailer.

headline.main: At a Small Shop in Colorado, Wal-Mart Beats a Union Once More

docs.abstract: Workers at Wal-Mart Tire & Lube Express in Loveland, Colo, vote 17 to 1 not to join United Food and Commercial Workers; union officials say Wal-Mart struck fear in workers with intensive campaign and transferred six antiunion workers into auto shop; will challenge outcome of vote with National Labor Relations Board; map; photo (M)
docs.snippet: In a setback for organized labor, workers for a Wal-Mart store in Colorado voted against unionizing.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: UNITED FOOD AND COMMERCIAL WORKERS UNION

docs.lead_paragraph: Jmeir White, 14 months old, weighed 10 pounds when he starved to death in August, in his parents' neatly kept home stocked with food. His death brought increased criticism to the New Jersey Division of Youth and Family Services, which had closed his family's case a month before he died. But the state's Office of the Child Advocate believes that Jmeir and three other children under state supervision died last year in part because the medical system failed them. In the four cases, a report concludes, improper diagnoses or failures in communication among doctors, hospitals and the child welfare system led to missed chances to save their lives.

headline.main: Poor Coordination Among Care Providers Contributed to Child Deaths, Report Says

docs.abstract: New Jersey's Office of Child Advocate reports that four children who died under state supervision in 2004 after suffering abuse might have been saved had it not been for improper diagnoses or failures in communications among doctors, hospitals and child welfare system; report adds momentum to effort to give better training to physicians and other medical personnel about signs of child abuse and child welfare system; one child, Jmeir White, was 14 months old and weighed only 10 pounds when he starved to death in Asbury Park in August, and his case shows how mistakes in care--some small, some glaring--can accumulate in fatal outcome; child's parents, Tahija Handberry and Wesley White, have been charged with manslaughter in boy's death; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Jmeir White's death brought increased criticism to the New Jersey Division of Youth and Family Services.

docs.lead_paragraph: The recently disclosed privacy breach at the data collection giant ChoicePoint, in which con artists gained access to the Social Security numbers, addresses and other personal data of nearly 145,000 people, has exposed the shortcomings of the laws governing the data-mining industry and consumer privacy. The company has mailed notification letters to the people whose privacy is known to have been compromised, and at least one lawsuit has been filed seeking class-action status for consumers whose information was leaked. And a Nigerian man in Los Angeles has been sentenced to 16 months in California state prison for his role in the fraud after pleading no contest to a single count of unlawful use of personal information.

headline.main: Breach Points Up Flaws in Privacy Laws

docs.abstract: Recently disclosed privacy breach at data collection company ChoicePoint, in which con artists gained access to Social Security numbers, addresses and other personal data of nearly 145,000 people, has exposed shortcomings of laws governing data-mining industry and consumer privacy; Nigerian man in Los Angeles has been sentenced to 16 months in California state prison for his role in fraud after pleading no contest to single count of unlawful use of personal information; bigger effect of breach may be its exposure of patchwork of sometimes conflicting state and federal rules that govern consumer privacy and commercial data vendors; state and federal regulators and lawmakers have started calling for updating of those rules, which never envisioned power of gatherers to amass and distribute vast digital dossiers on ordinary citizens; critics say current laws, in focusing too closely on industry-specific uses of information rather than on protecting privacy of individuals in databases, have failed to keep pace with emergence of such data miners; photos (M)
docs.snippet: The privacy breach at the data collection giant ChoicePoint has exposed the shortcomings of the laws governing the data-mining industry.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration predicted Wednesday that government would account for nearly half of all the nation's health care spending by 2014. Further, it said, total health spending will double in a decade, to $3.6 trillion in 2014 from $1.8 trillion last year, while gross domestic product, the total output of goods and services, grows more slowly. As a result, health spending will constitute 18.7 percent of the economy by 2014, up from an estimated 15.4 percent last year, the administration said.

headline.main: Health Costs Will Keep Rising, U.S. Says, Along With Government Share of Paying Them

docs.abstract: Bush administration predicts that government will account for nearly half of all nation's health care spending by 2014; says total health spending will double in decade, to $3.6 trillion, while gross domestic product grows more slowly; says result will be that health spending will constitute 18.7 percent of economy by 2014, up from 15.4 percent last year; graph (M)
docs.snippet: The Bush administration predicted that government would account for nearly half of all the nation's health care spending by 2014.
